Topic.Title: ARM can't manufacture its own products, so Toshiba scraps ARM tablets, notebooks

Message.Msg: Intel's strategy is to flood the market with cheap atom mobile chips that are vendor independent like their PC chips. If you know anything about computers you would know that armh chips are vendor specific, therefore are not fluid. Being more fluid comes at a cost and are less efficient.

Topic.Title: Getanid16 pumping ARM servers that don't even exist, LOL!

Message.Msg: Might not happen at all. They got the same barrier crossing over like Intel crossing over to mobile as long as Intel can keep up with Moore's law. I actually think Intel has a better chance crossing over to mobile if they can get their chips to become competitive with arm in terms of power and efficiency because they are just concentrating on chip design and not the end product itself. They will eventually flood the market with cheap mobile chips. If phone makers can cut cost using cheap intel mobile chips, they with most definately use them if the supply is constant and dependable, unlike fabless vendors that rely on their fabs that has tons of other customers that are pressuring them.

Topic.Title: ARM can't manufacture its own products, so Toshiba scraps ARM tablets, notebooks

Message.Msg: That's true. Intel might be the better way to go in the future because the x86 chips are more fluid. ----- Fluid? What does that mean? If you are talking about binary compatibility, ARM CPU's from different vendors for a specific revision of the ISA are binary compatible (much like x86).

Topic.Title: Applied Micro's X-Gene server chip ARMed to the teeth

Message.Msg: The idea that you can solve everything with architecture is lame. The chips will just keep getting bigger and bigger. Don't believe it? Just look at the thickness of the new iPad. And feel the heat. It's all about the fabrication. Intel has it. ARM doesn't. End of story... ----- You can't solve everything with architecture, but it can go a long way. If ARM64 is as clean and elegant as some suggest it means that It will be quick to implement and it will reduce the number of transistors needed to implement it (thus reducing the pressure of needing the newest node). As for the iPad, the thickness/heat issue is due to the screen/battery combo.

Topic.Title: Clint Eastwood absolutely KILLED IT at the DNC

Message.Msg: "Shouldn't that be everyones goal, to be rich. If you don't want more money, why are you investing in the stock market ? Obama speak = rich is bad, poor is good, Why don't you give everything you own away, and then we'll see if you practice what you preach. Your goal should be to become as poor as the poorest church mouse." *** Indeed, then why don't we make the tax rate for the rich zero? Your assumptions are absurd. You equate rich being good with making the rich better off and giving them whatever they ask for.. Only a #$%$ thinks those are the same thing. No Democrat thinks rich is bad and poor is good. The problem is that what you want for the rich comes at the expense of the middle class. America's success and economic stability are based on having a healthy middle class. I'm sick of the rich attempting to soak the middle class beyond anything that approaches reasonable. There hasn't been a Republican president since Eisenhower that has balanced a budget. And where did all this excessive spending go? It went to defense spending and tax cuts. Bush by himself engaged us in two wars and then didn't pay for either one. Instead he gave the rich an enormous tax cut. There is no reality in which this isn't irresponsible. The idea that Ryan really cares about cutting spending is a non-starter. He only wants to cut spending so he can generate more tax cuts - for the rich. He favors tax cuts over insurance for little kids, over education - in fact, there is nothing on Ryan's priority list above tax cuts. You guys got a huge tax cut under Bush and here you are with your hand out again. In the worst economic times in decades you want yet another free hand out. Well, guess what? It's time to put something back into the system that allowed you the opportunity to become rich.

And you think that will result in economic prosperity this time. Romney and Ryan have promised to create 12 million jobs. The only problem is that when people ask (and a lot have) exactly how that's going to happen the response is complete silence. Let me say it again: Republicans have no plan to restore jobs or create economic prosperity. Go ahead - Make my day. Explain to me what the plan is...

Message.Title: Bernanke paves the way for more stimulus
Message.Msg: From CNNMoney: Federal Reserve Chairman Ben Bernanke made his strongest case yet for more easing, during a high-profile speech in Jackson Hole, Wyo., Friday. Bernanke staunchly defended the Federal Reserve's two previous rounds of large asset purchases, saying they drove stocks higher, improved financial markets and created more than 2 million jobs. He also refuted several potential risks associated with those policies and talked up their benefits. "The odds are strong that the Fed's asset purchases will make money for the taxpayers, reducing the federal deficit and debt," Bernanke said. "And, of course, to the extent that monetary policy helps strengthen the economy and raise incomes, the benefits for the U.S. fiscal position would be substantial." The chairman also hinted that a third round of asset purchases known as quantitative easing -- or QE3 -- could be coming, by reiterating the Fed's willingness to pull the trigger. "The Federal Reserve will provide additional policy accommodation as needed to promote a stronger economic recovery and sustained improvement in labor market conditions in a context of price stability." Bernanke added that the economy "is obviously far from satisfactory," pointing to 8.3% unemployment and the weak job market as a "grave concern" causing "enormous suffering and waste of human talent." The Fed also sees the fiscal cliff and Europe's debt crisis as major threats to U.S. economic growth, and that gloomy outlook seems to have lowered the bar for the Fed to provide more stimulus. In previous statements, the central bank has pledged to provide stimulus only if the economy weakens further, but more recently that language has changed to say the Fed will act if the economy merely stays the same. Bernanke seemed to back up that view Friday, suggesting that the Fed needs to consider acting preemptively, to "take out insurance against the realization of downside risk" -- a view often expressed by his number two in command, Vice-Chairwoman Janet Yellen. U.S. stocks initially pulled back when Bernanke began speaking, but quickly moved higher after investors digested the speech as an assurance that additional stimulus is likely.
